section.title: Preparing &sr;
section.para: Before starting &sr;, initialize the environment variables SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR, SCIRUN_DATA, and SCIRUN_DATASET. The following sections describe the purpose and use of these variables.

section.title: Dynamic Compilation
section.para: Before starting &sr; users should be aware of a feature called Dynamic Compilation.

Dynamic compilation is a technique used by &sr; to discover and generate code for the data types and algorithms used by modules in networks. This is done at runtime and is done once for each new data type and algorithm encountered. This technique provides a number of benefits (not discussed here).

By default, code generated by dynamic compilation is stored in the directory build_dir/on-the-fly-libs for source installations and /usr/local/&sr;/bin/on-the-fly-libs for rpm installations. The location of dynamically generated code can be changed by setting the value of the environment variable SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR to the desired directory For example, in a shell terminal type:
mkdir ~/&sr;_otf
then for sh-type shells type:
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=~/&sr;_otf export SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR
and for csh-type shells type:
setenv SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR ~/&sr;_otf
Changing the location of the on-the-fly library directory provides a number of benefits described later.

The location of the on-the-fly directory can also be changed by setting the value of SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR in the .scirunrc file. This file is read by &sr; at startup. .scirunrc could contain, for example:
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=$(HOME)/&sr;_otf
See the &sr; Users Guide for more information on the use of .scirunrc.

note.para: It is recommended that each &sr; user create an on-the-fly library directory in their home directory, and set the value of SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR to point to this directory.

section.para:
Customizing the value of this variable for each &sr; user has the following benefits:
It allows multiple users to run the same instance of &sr; (at the same time) without the worry of dynamic compilation conflicts. For example, by specifying an on-the-fly-libs directory in their home directory, a user can run the same shared &sr; installed in /usr/local that another user is already running.
It allows a /usr/local installation of &sr; to be secure by not requiring that /usr/local/…/on-the-fly-libs be writable by all, which is a potential security risk.
It allows greater debugging and multiple build support by allowing the user to change dynamically compiled code locations between instances of &sr;.

section.title: Accessing Data Sets
section.para: The environment variables SCIRUN_DATA and SCIRUN_DATASET specify the complete path to a &sr; data set. SCIRUN_DATA specifies a directory that contains a collection of data set directories. SCIRUN_DATA is used in conjunction with SCIRUN_DATASET to specify the full path of a data set. SCIRUN_DATASET specifies a specific data set directory.
When working with &sr;'s tutorial, the value of SCIRUN_DATA must refer to the sample data sets directory, &sr;Data.

for sh-type shells type:
SCIRUN_DATA=path-to-&sr;Data export SCIRUN_DATA
for csh-type shells type:
setenv SCIRUN_DATA path-to-&sr;Data
SCIRUN_DATASET must refer to one of the data set directories within &sr;Data, e.g. utahtorso:
SCIRUN_DATASET=utahtorso export SCIRUN_DATASET
or
setenv SCIRUN_DATA utahtorso
